articles.title: Sales of electric cars hit record high in September
articles.summary: Sales of fully electric or hybrid vehicles made up more than half of all new car registrations in the UK last month.
articles.content:
Sales of electric cars hit record high in September

4 hours ago Share Save Michael Race Business reporter Share Save

Getty Images

Electric vehicle (EV) sales in the UK hit a record high last month, according to the latest industry figures. Sales of pure battery electric vehicles (BEV) grew by almost a third to 72,779 in September, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers (SMMT), while sales of plug-in hybrid cars grew even faster. It means sales of fully electric or hybrid vehicles made up more than half of all new car registrations in the UK last month. The SMMT said sales were driven by carmakers offering discounts, a larger choice of models, and the introduction of the government's grant scheme.

While registrations of BEVs rose last month, the overwhelming majority - 71.4% - were bought by businesses or to be used in fleets. However, the number of private buyers of fully electric cars has risen in the past year, and the SMMT said zero-emission vehicles now accounted for more than one in five (22.1%) new cars registered so far in 2025. SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes said electrified vehicles were "powering market growth after a sluggish summer". Industry investment in electric vehicles was "paying off", he said, despite consumer demand "trailing ambition". Mr Hawes added the government's electric car grant scheme, in which eligible vehicles get a £3,750 discount as part of efforts to encourage drivers to move away from petrol and diesel vehicles, would help "break down one of the barriers" holding back people making the switch.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant increase in electric vehicle sales in the UK, reflecting a positive shift toward zero-emission transportation. This has broad environmental benefits by reducing reliance on fossil fuels and lowering emissions. The story includes substantial details about sales growth, government incentives, and market impact, indicating a meaningful and measurable positive change for society and the environment.

Nearly one-third more fully electric cars were sold compared to before, with 72,779 battery electric vehicles (BEVs) bought. Plug-in hybrid car sales grew even faster. **Impact** – This is important because it shows more people and businesses are choosing cars that produce no or less pollution. So far in 2025, zero-emission vehicles make up over 22% of new car registrations, a sign that cleaner cars are becoming more popular and affordable.

articles.title: Small farmers are more squeezed than ever. A California grant program offers a lifeline.
articles.summary:
A recent report shows that the Farm to School grant program, which started in 2021, has been effective at supporting small, mid-sized, and socially or economically disadvantaged farmers. The program is open to applications from farmers, schools, child care centers, and other organizations focused on assisting schools with local food procurement or other food education initiatives. It’s designed to both support local producers and bring more fresh, sustainably grown produce to students across California. 

It’s also a sign of how some states are continuing efforts to support farmers in the face of mounting federal cuts.
articles.content:
When Javier Zamora started his organic berry farm more than a decade ago, he was working with just an acre and a half of land in Monterey County, near California’s central coast. Today, he and his crew grow strawberries, raspberries, and blackberries, as well as vegetables and flowers, on more than 100 acres. Recently, Zamora participated in a farmers market hosted by a San Jose school that serves a largely Hispanic community.

At the event, Zamora found that he was not just bringing fresh produce to students, but introducing them to foods they’d never tried before.

“They never get to see a brussels sprout or a purple potato and they definitely do not ever get to taste a French strawberry, like Mara des Bois, or a golden raspberry,” Zamora said. “So it makes me feel really, really nice to connect with those people.”

Making inroads with other communities outside of his farm is important to Zamora, who comes from a farming family in Mexico. That got a lot easier after purchasing a refrigerated van, with the help of a $150,000 grant from the California Department of Food and Agriculture, or CDFA. Now, he can deliver to clients as far as Sacramento, bringing his berries to school districts some three hours away.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

“We’ve had it for two years now, and it’s incredible. It’s a beautiful thing, and drives nicely,” he said of the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter van. “And we can deliver up to 400 cases of strawberries, which is really good.”

A recent report shows that the farm-to-school grant program, which started in 2021, has been effective at supporting small, mid-sized, and socially or economically disadvantaged farmers. The program is open to applications from farmers, schools, child care centers, and other organizations focused on assisting schools with local food procurement or other food education initiatives. It’s designed to both support local producers and bring more fresh, sustainably grown produce to students across California.

It’s also a sign of how some states are continuing efforts to support farmers in the face of mounting federal cuts.

In 2022, an independent team of researchers from UC Berkeley, UC Agriculture and Natural Resources, the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and other groups, set out to evaluate how well the grant program was adhering to the state’s roadmap for building a more equitable and sustainable regional food system. The roadmap initially established a goal of allocating 25 percent of funds in 2022, followed by 40 percent of funds in 2024, to those small and mid-sized farmers historically left out of opportunities in the food system.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

According to the report, the program has far outdone that: Last year, 100 percent of grant funding went to these prioritized farmers, up from 84 percent in 2022.

One of the other goals of the grant program is to support and incentivize farmers in adopting climate-smart practices like cover cropping, which stabilize and improve soil chemistry and improve soil’s ability to store carbon. On this note, the program has somewhat mixed results: The evaluation team found that most of the money awarded by CDFA has not gone to farmers experimenting with climate-smart ag for the first time. Instead, grants are going to growers who are already implementing these practices, said Beth Katz, one of the contributors to the report.

Katz is curious about how the grant program could better assist farmers who are new to climate-smart ag, but believes supporting farmers already using these practices is still beneficial for the environment. In California and nationwide, small farms are struggling to make ends meet in an age of cuts to federal programs. If state dollars help these farmers stay in business, it means they can continue implementing greener practices, argued Katz, who also heads the Food Insight Group, a food systems research firm.

For Zamora, buying his refrigerated van, which came out to around $100,000, wouldn’t have been possible without support from CDFA. “Many farmers, we just don’t have that kind of dough to buy something like that, so these grants are just an incredible tool for us,” he said. He hopes to apply for additional funding during the next grant cycle — maybe for more vans, a walk-in cooler, or other kinds of infrastructure.

California’s progress demonstrates how states can aid farmers that depended on federal programs that promoted purchasing local food, which have been closed or underfunded by the Trump administration. With the federal government shutdown, which began on Wednesday, U.S. farmers are feeling more squeezed than ever. The Trump administration’s track record with farm country has been mixed this year, as the president’s trade war with China and most other parts of the world has meant farmers must find new markets for their crops.

Losing access to vital public services due to congressional infighting is likely to make this financial pressure worse. For example, the Farm Service Agency, a subagency of the U.S. Department of Agriculture that provides farm loans and disaster aid and runs conservation programs, closed offices around the country as the ag department furloughed half its workforce. As Republicans and Democrats blame each other for the funding stalemate, which is expected to last at least until next week, Trump and his allies are threatening resorting to layoffs or permanent cuts if a deal isn’t reached soon.

State programs like California’s can help offset some of the economic uncertainty farmers face while the fight over funding plans drags on. “I think it’s just all the more important,” said Katz. “And I think that all the investments that California as a state is continuing to make in school meal programs and food systems infrastructure broadly are a bit of a buffer” for growers and consumers alike.

The farm-to-school grant program has also been successful in helping schools in remote areas access local produce by working with organizations like food hubs.

At Julian Union School District in San Diego County, building a program where students could engage with local farmers would have involved hour and a half drives, said Mati Moon, a garden education coordinator at Julian Pathways, a nonprofit that provides wraparound services for Julian Union. Many years ago, the district received a farm-to-school grant from the USDA — but the rural location of the schools made it difficult to connect with farmers, said Moon.

Working with CDFA has been more fruitful. Moon applied for a farm-to-school grant on behalf of Julian Pathways, which does food procurement for the school district’s nutrition program. Upon receiving the funding, Moon’s contact at CDFA encouraged her to contact a local food hub that distributes fresh produce throughout San Diego County. Moon was able to convince the hub to deliver to her community by starting a community-supported agriculture, or CSA, program and signing on about 75 families to receive produce from the hub. Through that, “we were able to secure some regular deliveries up in the Julian area to support our nutrition program” using grant dollars, said Moon.

Establishing a relationship with a food hub that might have previously considered Julian too far away to work with has been a boon for the community. “Tying into that network, which allows schools and businesses to access produce from all over the county in an easier, more cost-effective way, has been a game-changer,” said Moon.

Zamora dreams of opening his own food hub one day and supporting more farmers hoping to sell their food locally. He notes that his farm has lost several clients, as USDA funding that they once relied on dries up. He remains hopeful, though, about his business — and also hopes more of his peers can take advantage of grant programs like the ones CDFA is offering as they devise new ways to stay afloat. “In at least my case, what I’ve applied for and what I got has been nothing but a blessing,” said Zamora.

Correction: An earlier version of this article misspelled the name of the organization headed by Beth Katz.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a California state grant program that effectively supports small, mid-sized, and disadvantaged farmers by helping them supply fresh, sustainably grown produce to schools, benefiting both local agriculture and student nutrition. The story demonstrates significant real-world benefits with broad societal and environmental implications, including food system equity and sustainability.

articles.title: For the restructuring of coal regions, new 14 million EU funds
articles.summary: The Slovenian coal regions are rapidly transforming and restructuring with European funds, and the exit from coal is expected to be completed by 2033.
articles.content:
The Slovenian coal regions are rapidly transforming and restructuring with European funds, and the exit from coal is expected to be completed by 2033.

Ljubljana – The Ministry of Cohesion and Regional Development has approved over 14 million euros of European funds for a public call for co-financing research and development and demonstration-pilot projects in the Zasavje and Savinja-Šaleška coal mining regions under the Just Transition Fund.

“We want to support at least 23 consortia of companies in both coal mining regions that will implement projects for the development of new or improved products, processes, or services with higher added value and market potential, which in turn increases the competitiveness of the economy,” the ministry announced.

“Thus, the non-repayable European funds from the Just Transition Fund will be used for the economic restructuring of the Zasavje and Savinja-Šaleška coal mining regions towards a transition to a low-carbon, circular, and digital economy,” emphasized the responsible minister Aleksander Jevšek.

For the Zasavje coal mining region, 4.42 million euros will be allocated, while 10 million euros will be allocated for the Savinja-Šaleška region. The mentioned call is part of the activities for the restructuring of both coal mining regions, which will be supported by more than 250 million euros from the EU Just Transition Fund, and it is expected to be completed by 2033 at the latest. (October 2)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant and concrete positive action involving over 14 million euros in EU funds to support the economic restructuring of Slovenian coal regions towards a low-carbon, circular, and digital economy. This transition away from coal by 2033 has broad environmental and societal benefits, supported by a substantial EU Just Transition Fund. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful policy-driven impact on climate action and economic transformation.
articles.personality_title: Slovenia invests 14 million euros to transform coal regions by 2033
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Slovenia has coal mining regions that have long depended on coal for jobs and energy. The European Union wants to help these areas move away from coal to cleaner and more modern industries by 2033.

**What happened** – The Slovenian Ministry of Cohesion and Regional Development approved over 14 million euros from the European Union’s Just Transition Fund. This money will support projects in two coal regions called Zasavje and Savinja-Šaleška. The funds will help at least 23 groups of companies develop new products, services, or ways of working that create more value and improve the local economy.

**Impact** – This funding is part of a larger plan with more than 250 million euros to help these coal regions change to cleaner, digital, and circular economies. It means fewer jobs and money will depend on coal, which is better for the environment and helps the regions grow in new ways. It shows a clear plan to help workers and businesses adjust to a future without coal.

**What's next step** – The projects supported by this funding will start soon, focusing on innovation and economic growth. By 2033, the goal is to finish the transition so these regions no longer rely on coal but have strong, sustainable economies.

**One-sentence takeaway** – With 14 million euros in EU support, Slovenia is actively helping its coal regions develop new industries and move away from coal by 2033.

articles.title: Scooped by a cupcake business: why we called our green-cement company Sublime Systems
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 02 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02670-zChief executive and co-founder Leah Ellis browsed a rhyming dictionary before adapting a word that leapt out after discovering her first choice was already taken.
articles.content:
After looking for words that rhymed with lime, Sublime was the immediate and obvious winner.Credit: Mikhail Glabets

The meaning behind our moniker Sublime Systems, based in Somerville, Massachusetts, has developed a way to manufacture ‘clean’ cement using an electrochemical process which improves efficiency, durability and aesthetics, and avoids the carbon release caused by conventional production. The firm was set up in 2020 and now has more than 100 employees. In the penultimate article of a six-part series about science company names and how to choose them, co-founder and chief executive Leah Ellis reveals how she came up with Sublime Systems.

For about 18 months, I was doing my postdoc at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Cambridge, working on what was to become Sublime Systems. At that point, my co-founder, Yet-Ming Chiang, a materials scientist at MIT, engineer and serial entrepreneur, recognized it was the right time to spin it off from the university as a start-up company. At that stage, it needed a name.

In my view, coming up with a name is both important, because it sets the tone, and not important. The name is just a label.

The key reactive ingredient in cement — and the most carbon intensive — is lime, calcium oxide. So, I started there, browsing a rhyming dictionary for words that rhymed with lime. Sublime was the immediate and obvious winner.

In contrast to the grey cement made through the conventional process of burning limestone with bituminous coal, the manufacturing process we use to create cement results in a whiter version that is more purified, consistent in terms of both colour and quality, and beautiful.

I felt that the word Sublime encapsulated the spirit of excellence, transcendence and purity that we intend to exemplify as we build a technology and a company that we hope will change the world — and the inherent properties of cement itself.

Everyone quickly agreed on the name; it wasn’t a contentious decision. There was no ‘back and forth’, no other candidates. It immediately jumped out.

Striving for the sublime

We added ‘Systems’ because Sublime had already been taken by a cupcake company. But there was a second, more meaningful reason: our technology takes rocks and breaks them into their constituent minerals. That ‘Systems’ is plural is important. Although we’re addressing cement first, we hope that this technology can be applied to mining broadly, to process minerals from sources in which they were previously inaccessible, such as industrial wastes. So that is why the name references multiple systems — first, for cement manufacturing, and others in the future, such as sourcing material from incinerated electronic devices.

Some people, even those in the cement business, don’t get the meaning right away, and only months later do they understand. I think that’s kind of fun. Others are confused because there’s no sublimation in our process. But I do think that it’s evocative of something that transcends.

articles.personality_title: Sublime Systems: A new name for cleaner, greener cement
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Cement is a key building material but making it usually releases a lot of carbon dioxide, which harms the environment. A company in Massachusetts is working on a new way to make cement that avoids this pollution.

**What happened** – Sublime Systems, started in 2020 by Leah Ellis and her team, uses an electrochemical method to produce cement. This process makes cement that is cleaner, stronger, and looks better than regular cement. When choosing a name, Leah looked for words that rhyme with “lime,” a main ingredient in cement, and chose “Sublime.” They added “Systems” because the name “Sublime” was already taken by a cupcake business and because their technology works on multiple mineral systems.

**Impact** – This new cement could reduce the carbon pollution caused by traditional cement making, which is a big source of emissions worldwide. The technology also creates a whiter, more consistent cement that could improve building quality. Plus, the company hopes to use the same method to recycle minerals from waste, such as electronic trash, which could help reduce mining damage.

**What's next step** – Sublime Systems plans to keep developing their technology and apply it to other minerals beyond cement. This could lead to cleaner production methods in different industries and help turn waste into useful materials.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Sublime Systems is creating cleaner cement with a new process that could cut pollution and improve building materials while opening doors to recycling minerals from waste.
articles.personality_title_fr: Sublime Systems : un nouveau nom pour un ciment plus propre et écologique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le ciment est un matériau de construction essentiel, mais sa fabrication produit beaucoup de dioxyde de carbone, nocif pour l'environnement. Une entreprise du Massachusetts travaille sur une nouvelle méthode pour fabriquer du ciment sans cette pollution.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Sublime Systems, créée en 2020 par Leah Ellis et son équipe, utilise un procédé électrochimique pour produire du ciment. Ce ciment est plus propre, plus solide et plus esthétique que le ciment classique. Pour choisir un nom, Leah a cherché des mots rimant avec « lime » (chaux), un ingrédient principal du ciment, et a choisi « Sublime ». Ils ont ajouté « Systems » car « Sublime » était déjà pris par une entreprise de cupcakes, et parce que leur technologie agit sur plusieurs systèmes minéraux.

**Impact** – Ce nouveau ciment pourrait réduire la pollution carbone causée par la fabrication traditionnelle, qui est une grande source d'émissions dans le monde. Cette technologie produit aussi un ciment plus blanc et plus uniforme, améliorant la qualité des constructions. En plus, l'entreprise espère recycler des minéraux issus des déchets, comme les déchets électroniques, ce qui pourrait limiter les dégâts liés à l'extraction minière.

**Prochaine étape** – Sublime Systems prévoit de continuer à développer sa technologie et de l'appliquer à d'autres minéraux au-delà du ciment. Cela pourrait permettre des méthodes de production plus propres dans plusieurs industries et transformer les déchets en ressources utiles.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Sublime Systems crée un ciment plus propre grâce à un nouveau procédé qui pourrait réduire la pollution, améliorer les matériaux de construction et recycler les minéraux issus des déchets.
articles.personality_title_es: Sublime Systems: un nuevo nombre para un cemento más limpio y ecológico
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El cemento es un material de construcción clave, pero su producción suele liberar mucho dióxido de carbono, que daña el medio ambiente. Una empresa en Massachusetts está desarrollando una forma nueva de hacer cemento que evita esta contaminación.

**Qué pasó** – Sublime Systems, fundada en 2020 por Leah Ellis y su equipo, usa un método electroquímico para fabricar cemento. Este proceso produce un cemento más limpio, fuerte y con mejor apariencia que el cemento tradicional. Al elegir un nombre, Leah buscó palabras que rimen con “lime” (cal), un ingrediente principal del cemento, y eligió “Sublime”. Añadieron “Systems” porque el nombre “Sublime” ya estaba ocupado por un negocio de cupcakes y porque su tecnología trabaja con varios sistemas minerales.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo cemento podría reducir la contaminación por carbono causada por el cemento tradicional, que es una gran fuente de emisiones en el mundo. Además, el cemento es más blanco y consistente, lo que puede mejorar la calidad de las construcciones. La empresa también espera usar esta tecnología para reciclar minerales de desechos, como la basura electrónica, lo que ayudaría a reducir el daño de la minería.

**Próximo paso** – Sublime Systems planea seguir mejorando su tecnología y aplicarla a otros minerales además del cemento. Esto podría llevar a métodos de producción más limpios en diferentes industrias y ayudar a convertir desechos en materiales útiles.

**Resumen en una frase** – Sublime Systems está creando un cemento más limpio con un nuevo proceso que podría reducir la contaminación y mejorar los materiales de construcción mientras abre camino para reciclar minerales de desechos.
